title: 113_s2423
content: The "Veterans Access to Care Accountability Act" mandates audits by the Comptroller General of the United States on VA medical facilities to ensure compliance with access standards for veterans. It aims to improve wait times for hospital care, medical services, and other healthcare for veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must notify eligible veterans within 48 hours of a report finding wait times over 30 days for care. Efforts must be made to schedule appointments within seven days at a VA facility or with a non-Department provider. Any report described in this subsection includes reports from the Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Comptroller General of the United States, the Department itself, or other organizations regarding the provision of hospital care, medical services, or other health care to veterans within Veterans Integrated Service Networks or medical facilities. Privacy rules regarding the disclosure of personal information of eligible veterans seeking care from the Department of Veterans Affairs are not altered by this section. An eligible veteran is defined as someone who is eligible for hospital care, medical services, or other health care under the laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. SEC. 4. Executive compensation and bonuses accountability at Department of Veterans Affairs. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs if a facility director purposefully misrepresents patient records to conceal failures in compliance with care standards for personal gain. The Inspector General must report misrepresentations by facility directors to the Secretary, who must then withhold performance awards until issues are resolved. Performance reviews and promotions for directors must be monitored by the Secretary. The Inspector General must evaluate if a director knew about misrepresentations at a medical facility before considering them for promotion. Names of implicated officials cannot be made public. The Inspector General's role in this process is in addition to their existing responsibilities under the Inspector General Act of 1978.
